ygData.subject: Re: Connection enable flag in NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin, what do you do with the enable bit in your implementation? It s not completely clear what it means to say the enable bit doesn t have an advantage

Colin, what do you do with the enable bit in your implementation?  
It's not completely clear what it means to say the enable bit 
doesn't have an advantage (which may very well be true) since what 
really matters is how it's being used, i.e. when do links become 
disabled, and how do they (or do they at all) become reenabled?  Of 
course, there is a standard way I use them in my version of NEAT, 
but there are so many ways it could be done and some might actually 
be better than others.
ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> I spotted a bug whereby when I reset the enabled flag on an new 
genome's 
> connection I also reset it on the parent! This most likely had a 
> detrimental effect on searching and in fact my update of 
yesterday's 
> graph indicates that this might have been the case:
> 
> http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/enablebitgraph2.png
> 
> The two experimetents (with and without the enable bit) are now 
much 
> more in-line with each other, whereas enablebitgraph.png showed 
slightly 
> better results without the enable bit. I had put this difference 
down to 
> not avergaing over enough runs, which could still be the case, but 
the 
> new graph does show four very well matched lines.
> 
> Colin.
> 
> 
> 
> Colin Green wrote:
> 
> >Maybe some of you will find this of interest...
> >
> >As a precursor to my phased searching work I thought about 
simplfying 
> >the NEAT genome ever so slightly by eliminating the 'enable' flag 
on a 
> >connection gene. I just ran a experiment using my new OCR code 
and, 
> >although it's not the most thorough scientific analysis it does 
seem to 
> >hint that the enable bit isn't all that beneficial.
> >
> >I ran the same search 10 times, 5 with the enable bit, 5 without. 
Each 
> >run was 1000 generations. I have produced a graph that shows the 
average 
> >of the runs here:
> >
> >http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/enablebitgraph.png
> >
> >
> >Colin
> >
> >  
> >
